intro: Agalinis auriculata, commonly known as the auriculate bluemink, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, tubular flowers. The leaves are opposite and have a distinctive auriculate (ear-shaped) base, giving the plant its common name. It typically grows in moist, open habitats such as prairies and woodland edges. The plant is known for its delicate appearance and is often found in areas with well-drained soil.
